Authors:
Ramona Oviedo, Javier Francisco-Ortega, Arne A. Anderberg,
Hong Liu, Jennifer Trusty
Title:
Molecular phylogenetics of the Caribbean genera Rhodogeron
and Sachsia (Asteraceae).
Abstract:
Rhodogeron Griseb. and Sachsia Griseb. (Asteraceae) are
two Caribbean genera. Rhodogeron is restricted to Cuba, whereas Sachsia
is found in Cuba, the Bahamas, South Florida and Hispaniola. A
phylogenetic study of nucleotide sequences of the chloroplast gene ndhF
and of the internal transcribed spacers (ITS) of the nuclear ribosomal
DNA shows that these two genera form a monophyletic group. The ndhF
phylogeny places Rhodogeron and Sachsia within the tribe Plucheeae but
with only very weak bootstrap support (59%). The ITS phylogeny indicates
the serpentine areas of Cuba are the ancestral habitat for these genera,
with a colonization route from Cuba toward the Bahamas and Florida. In
addition, this study supports previous taxonomic treatments which
considered S. divaricata Griseb. and S. polycephala Griseb. to be
conspecific. Finally, Rhodogeron is the sister taxon to Sachsia, and we
propose that it should be maintained as a distinct monospecific
genus.
